articles.headline: As Subprime Market Implodes, a Contrarian Prospers
articles.snippet: As the markets rise and fall, the owner of United Capital Markets has been able to profit handsomely by taking advantage of the wide swings.
articles.abstract: As the markets rise and fall, the owner of United Capital Markets has been able to profit handsomely by taking advantage of the wide swings.
articles.lead_paragraph: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. — In a clubby market where securities based on risky mortgages, credit card debt and other financial assets are traded, John Devaney is known for making brash pronouncements — and for often being proved right.

articles.headline: U.S. Is Extending Tours of Army
articles.snippet: Most active duty units in Iraq and Afghanistan will serve for 15 months, rather than 12.
articles.abstract: Most active duty units in Iraq and Afghanistan will serve for 15 months, rather than 12.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 11 — The military announced Wednesday that most active duty Army units now in Iraq and Afghanistan and those sent in the future would serve 15-month tours, three months longer than the standard one-year tour.

articles.headline: A Faster Wi-Fi World Is Coming
articles.snippet: Makers of Wi-Fi routers boast of 5 times the speed and 15 times the range, but be sure to read the footnotes.
articles.abstract: Makers of Wi-Fi routers boast of 5 times the speed and 15 times the range, but be sure to read the footnotes.
articles.lead_paragraph: “When I was your age,” we’ll someday tell our awe-struck grandchildren, “wireless Internet was available only in isolated hot spots 100 feet across!”

articles.headline: Some Suspect Chemical Mix in Pet Food
articles.snippet: U.S. regulators are investigating whether melamine, the chemical linked to recent pet deaths, was mixed into wheat gluten in China.
articles.abstract: U.S. regulators are investigating whether melamine, the chemical linked to recent pet deaths, was mixed into wheat gluten in China.
articles.lead_paragraph: XUZHOU, China, April 10 — Behind an unmarked gate in this booming city well north of Shanghai lies a large building at the heart of an investigation over tainted pet food that has killed at least 16 cats and dogs in the United States, sickened 12,000 and prompted a nationwide recall.

articles.headline: Films From the Weinsteins Falter, but the Brothers Stay Focused
articles.snippet: The Weinstein Company is facing the kind of difficulties that would sink a less tenacious start-up.
articles.abstract: The Weinstein Company is facing the kind of difficulties that would sink a less tenacious start-up.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, April 11 — As last weekend’s box-office take for the heavily promoted “Grindhouse” tumbled in at just $11.6 million, a chilly realization came with the numbers: Not all is well with the Weinstein Company.

articles.headline: All Charges Dropped in Duke Case
articles.snippet: North Carolina’s attorney general said an overzealous district attorney had wrongly accused lacrosse players of sexual assault.
articles.abstract: North Carolina’s attorney general said an overzealous district attorney had wrongly accused lacrosse players of sexual assault.
articles.lead_paragraph: RALEIGH, N.C., April 11 — North Carolina’s attorney general declared three former Duke University lacrosse players accused of sexually assaulting a stripper innocent of all charges on Wednesday, ending a prosecution that provoked bitter debate over race, class and the tactics of the Durham County district attorney.
articles.byline: By Duff Wilson and David Barstow

articles.headline: NBC News Drops Imus Show Over Racial Remark
articles.snippet: The move came after several days of widening calls for Don Imus to lose his show both on MSNBC and CBS Radio.
articles.abstract: The move came after several days of widening calls for Don Imus to lose his show both on MSNBC and CBS Radio.
articles.lead_paragraph: NBC News dropped Don Imus yesterday, canceling his talk show on its MSNBC cable news channel a week after he made a racially disparaging remark about the Rutgers University women’s basketball team.
articles.byline: By Bill Carter and Louise Story

articles.headline: Citigroup to Eliminate 17,000 Jobs
articles.snippet: The banking giant announced a restructuring plan that eliminates 17,000 jobs and shifts another 9,500 positions overseas.
articles.abstract: The banking giant announced a restructuring plan that eliminates 17,000 jobs and shifts another 9,500 positions overseas.
articles.lead_paragraph: Citigroup has long carried the mantle as the world’s biggest bank in the world’s financial capital — big deals, big ambitions and in the last few years, big costs.

articles.headline: This Time, a Shock Jock’s Sidekick Fails
articles.snippet: Don Imus waded into trouble alongside Bernard McGuirk, instead of watching safely from the side.
articles.abstract: Don Imus waded into trouble alongside Bernard McGuirk, instead of watching safely from the side.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just before Don Imus infamously referred to the Rutgers women’s basketball team on his radio show on April 4 as “nappy-headed hos,” another voice could be heard describing them as “some hard-core hos.”

articles.headline: Civilian Claims on U.S. Suggest the Toll of War
articles.snippet: The military has paid $32 million to Iraqis and Afghans  for noncombat-related killings, injuries and damage.
articles.abstract: The military has paid $32 million to Iraqis and Afghans  for noncombat-related killings, injuries and damage.
articles.lead_paragraph: In February 2006, nervous American soldiers in Tikrit killed an Iraqi fisherman on the Tigris River after he leaned over to switch off his engine. A year earlier, a civilian filling his car and an Iraqi Army officer directing traffic were shot by American soldiers in a passing convoy in Balad, for no apparent reason.
